channel.title: Chrome under Windows 7
channel.description:
On a fresh install of Windows 7 Sunday, Chrome did not work. It just kept on loading pages I tried all sorts of things Google got me (from IE), and I got no where.
About an hour ago I decided to reinstall Windows 7. No joy after a second reinstall.
Please can you help me!
[size=1pt]I already know Windows sux[/size]

item.title: Chrome under Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

i was talking about windows

Read full topic

item.title: Chrome under Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:58, topic:379832”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=475674.msg3488151#msg3488151 date=1296763318]

‘Google Updater’ isn’t really just an automatic updater for chrome though is it? The windows computers I work on that have any google product installed, no matter how small, seem to all have this big ‘google_updater.exe’ program running continuously, why is that needed at all? (firefox checks for updates only when you run it, that’s nice)

I’ve heard about this, but my machine isn’t running it and I’m running both current release chrome and canary, which autoupdate fine.

Why don’t I have it
[/quote]

There is no ‘google updater’ under linux, since it just uses dpkg on debian-based distros anyway. Last time I used it on windows there was a google_updater.exe, hopefully they have gotten rid of it? I don’t know. [/quote]

Don’t know how it is on Windows, but on Mac I usually have my Chrome open all the time for days straight. At least once a week I get a really small ! icon on the Tool button and if I hover over it it says Chrome has downloaded updates but can’t finish them until Chrome is restarted. Never had that on Windows because I never kept it open that long. So for the most part Chrome updating is transparent to me.

Read full topic

item.title: Chrome under Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:56, topic:379832”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=475674.msg3485913#msg3485913 date=1296579837]
‘Google Updater’ isn’t really just an automatic updater for chrome though is it? The windows computers I work on that have any google product installed, no matter how small, seem to all have this big ‘google_updater.exe’ program running continuously, why is that needed at all? (firefox checks for updates only when you run it, that’s nice)
[/quote]

I’ve heard about this, but my machine isn’t running it and I’m running both current release chrome and canary, which autoupdate fine.

Why don’t I have it :/[/quote]

There is no ‘google updater’ under linux, since it just uses dpkg on debian-based distros anyway. Last time I used it on windows there was a google_updater.exe, hopefully they have gotten rid of it? I don’t know.

Read full topic

item.title: Chrome under Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @cumescape cumescape
item.description:
@cumescape wrote:

[quote=“Greeny, post:51, topic:379832”][quote author=Teh Spede link=topic=475674.msg3480490#msg3480490 date=1296078121]
firefox memory leaks <3
[/quote]

These.

Firefox takes days to start-up. I switched to Chrome about a year ago, and have never looked back. It’s minimal design means more space for web pages and all the extensions I had for Firefox are in Chrome.[/quote]Firefox takes like one second to open for me, I currently use Minefield and have no toolbars as they are useless… Maybe if you tried the Firefox beta 4.0 you would see this.

Read full topic

item.title: Chrome under Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Thug-life:

Chrome always feels like a lighter, efficient and generally more stable application.[/quote][quote=“Teh Spede, post:17, topic:379832”]firefox memory leaks <3

These.

Firefox takes days to start-up. I switched to Chrome about a year ago, and have never looked back. It’s minimal design means more space for web pages and all the extensions I had for Firefox are in Chrome.

Cumescape, some of the things in that post are an expected feature of modern browsers. A decent bug tracking system, address bar suggestions and an automatic updater.

I think I’ll go create an image likening IRC clients to botnets. Maybe XBL is a botnet? Wait, wait I’ve got it. Android phones are all part of a botnet too.

Read full topic

item.title: Chrome under Windows 7
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Some things in the Chrome UI are hard to find at times. Depends what you’re looking for and what you’re used to.

I still use Chrome however. afaik, flash doesn’t eat up 999999 memory when it comes to Chrome. When you would close Firefox after using a flash application, it would pretend that Firefox is still open.

Read full topic

item.description:

I BET YOU LOVE YOUR GOOGLE TOOLBAR.
[/quote]on chrome you just input your query in the URL field and it will work as a search engine “toolbar” for the configured default search engine

i’ve gotten so used to it tbh: ctrl + t, query, enter[/quote]

f6 type search term return = google im feeling lucky, it has been in firefox for years

ps placebo effect bitches
pps on an unrelated note, would anyone like to buy my miracle water that cures all aches pains and headaces?
ppps how can anyone like the chrome ui? it was the only thing that put me off chrome, along with the terrible extension support at the time and no performance gains
